en: Barocci Drawings: Watercolour and bodycolour or gouache

Both these terms describe the application of a transparent paint achieved by mixing pigments with an aqueous binding medium. The transparent appearance of these techniques is due to the high proportion of water used either to dissolve the colour or dilute the paint. When the effect is opaque this method is termed bodycolour or gouache. Italian artists used these practices to increase the range of tonalities in certain areas of the drawing or to underline shadows and the modelling of figures.

description: Both these terms describe the application of a transparent paint achieved by mixing pigments with an aqueous binding medium. The transparent appearance of these techniques is due to the high proportion of water used either to dissolve the colour or dilute the paint. When the effect is opaque this method is termed bodycolour or gouache. en: R43.1: Federico Barocci, Compositional study for Cornelis Cort's Print of 'The Madonna of the Cat' ('La Madonna del Gatto'), before 1577, black and red chalk, with touches of white bodycolour, indented with squared lines on white paper, (30 x 23.8 cm), (inv. 1994-5-14-55 recto, The British Museum, London) Barocci made this copy drawn after ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ to send to the Dutch printmaker Cornelis Cort in Rome as a scale model for an engraving. Barocci used three colours of chalk to convey the depth and warmth of the painting, which remained in the Marches. The incised outlines and squaring reveal Cort’s methods for transferring the design to the copper plate from which his engraving (1577), was printed in reverse. Even if this is not a proper cartoncino (small cartoon) and it was made after the completion of the painting, it shows the high level of finish which Barocci was seeking in his completed compositional studies. © The British Museum, London (3368x2679px)

NG29: Federico Barocci, The Madonna of the Cat ('La Madonna del Gatto'), probably about 1575, Oil on canvas, (112.7 x 92.7 cm) The young John the Baptist holds a goldfinch, a bird frequently kept as a pet but also a traditional symbol of Christ's Passion; the Baptist is teasing the cat shown in the left foreground by holding the bird above his head. The Virgin is suckling the Child and Saint Joseph looks on from the right.
NG 29 may be the picture painted, according to Bellori (1672), for Count Antonio Brancaleoni, who lived near Perugia. The design was engraved in reverse in 1577 by Cornelius Cort and the painting probably dates from about 1575. Numerous drawings made in preparation for NG 29 are known; a highly finished drawing made by Barocci in preparation for the engraving and formerly in the National Gallery is now in the British Museum.
The window and the bench in the background seem to be based on windows in the Palazzo Ducale, Urbino. There are several copies and workshop versions of the picture.
Cesarei collection, Perugia, by 1784; acquired in Italy by Buchanan, about 1805; collection of Revd Holwell Carr, 1807; by whom bequeathed, 1831.
Gould 1975, pp. 11-12
Emiliani 1985, I, pp. 93-103 Bequeathed by Revd Holwell Carr, 1831 (6000x4929px)
